instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the optimized CNN model in classifying DON levels in barley kernels and how accurate was it?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the optimized CNN model in classifying DON levels in barley kernels was accuracy. instruction: What machine learning methods were used in the study on the classification of DON levels in different genetic lines of barley kernels using HSI and CNN?
Output: The machine learning methods used in the study on the classification of DON levels in different genetic lines of barley kernels using HSI and CNN were logistic regression, support vector machine, stochastic gradient descent, K nearest neighbors, random forest, and CNN.

instruction: Can hyperspectral imaging (HSI) in combination with a convolutional neural network (CNN) be considered a superior method compared to traditional methods for classifying deoxynivalenol (DON) levels in different genetic lines of barley kernels?
Output: Yes, hyperspectral imaging (HSI) in combination with a convolutional neural network (CNN) can be considered a superior method compared to traditional methods for classifying deoxynivalenol (DON) levels in different genetic lines of barley kernels. The study evaluated the feasibility of using HSI and a CNN for this purpose and found that the simplified CNN model showed better performance than other machine learning models. The optimized CNN model was able to successfully distinguish barley grains with low levels of DON from those with higher levels, with an accuracy of 89.41%. Additionally, the lower levels of DON class I and class II were successfully distinguished based on the optimized CNN model, yielding a precision of 89.81%. These results suggest that HSI in tandem with CNN has great potential for discriminating DON levels in barley kernels.
